messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Free Sets in Planar Graphs: History and ApplicationsThis research is partially funded by the grants from NSERC and the University Research Chair of University of Ottawa.

Paper Abstract: A subset SùëÜS of vertices in a planar graph Gùê∫G is a free set if, for every set PùëÉP of |S|ùëÜ|S| points in the plane, there exists a straight-line crossing-free drawing of Gùê∫G in which vertices of SùëÜS are mapped to distinct points in PùëÉP. In this survey, we review ‚Ä¢ several equivalent definitions of free sets, ‚Ä¢ results on the existence of large free sets in planar graphs and subclasses of planar graphs, ‚Ä¢ and applications of free sets in graph drawing. The survey concludes with a list of open problems in this still very active research area.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Graphs with homeomorphically irreducible spanning trees",
        "Universal point subsets for planar graphs",
        "SEFE without mapping via large induced outerplane graphs in plane graphs",
        "On a tree and a path with no geometric simultaneous embedding",
        "Superpatterns and universal point sets",
        "Track layouts, layered path decompositions, and leveled planarity",
        "Column planarity and partially-simultaneous geometric embedding",
        "Column planarity and partial simultaneous geometric embedding for outerplanar graphs",
        "Trees in polyhedral graphs",
        "Small drawings of outerplanar graphs, series-parallel graphs, and other planar graphs",
        "Circumference of 3-connected claw-free graphs and large Eulerian subgraphs of 3-edge connected graphs",
        "Simultaneous embedding of planar graphs",
        "Longest cycles in 3-connected 3-regular graphs",
        "On embedding an outer-planar graph in a point set",
        "Connected dominating sets in triangulations",
        "A polynomial bound for untangling geometric planar graphs",
        "Selected open problems in graph drawing",
        "On simultaneous planar graph embeddings",
        "Upper bound constructions for untangling planar geometric graphs",
        "On universal point sets for planar graphs",
        "Straight line embeddings of planar graphs on point sets",
        "Untangling polygons and graphs",
        "Drawing planar graphs with many collinear vertices",
        "Matched drawings of planar graphs",
        "Graph theory, volume 173 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "The utility of untangling",
        "Dual circumference and collinear sets",
        "Every collinear set in a planar graph is free",
        "Characterization of unlabeled level planar trees",
        "Column planarity and partial simultaneous geometric embedding",
        "Straight-line drawings on restricted integer grids in two and three dimensions",
        "Small sets supporting f√°ry embeddings of planar graphs",
        "How to draw a planar graph on a grid",
        "On straight-line representation of planar graphs",
        "New bounds on the local and global edge-length ratio of planar graphs",
        "How many vertex locations can be arbitrarily chosen when drawing planar graphs?",
        "Untangling a planar graph",
        "Embedding a planar triangulation with vertices at specified points (solution to problem e3341)",
        "Shortness exponents of families of graphs",
        "Longest cycles in 3-connected cubic graphs",
        "Untangling planar graphs from a specified vertex position - hard cases",
        "Triangulating planar graphs while minimizing the maximum degree",
        "Circumference of 3-connected cubic graphs",
        "Regular planar graphs with faces of only two types and shortness parameters",
        "Untangling a polygon",
        "Monotone drawings of planar graphs",
        "On collinear sets in straight-line drawings",
        "The four-colour theorem",
        "A note on universal point sets for planar graphs",
        "Embedding planar graphs on the grid",
        "Convex maps",
        "A logarithmic bound for simultaneous embeddings of planar graphs",
        "Remarks on the colouring of maps",
        "On Hamilton circuits",
        "How to draw a graph",
        "Bemerkungen zum vierfarbenproblem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Free Sets in Planar Graphs: History and ApplicationsThis research is partially funded by the grants from NSERC and the University Research Chair of University of Ottawa., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
